--- title: "Consumer Theory" subtitle: "Lecture 5: Budget Set and Budget Constraint" author: "Paulo Fagandini" date: today date-format: "YYYY" format: revealjs: from: markdown+emoji theme: [default, custom.scss] transition: slide slide-number: true chalkboard: true scrollable: false footer: "Economics of Tourism | Lecture 5" logo: ../images/logo.png width: 1600 height: 900 --- ::: {.cell} ::: ## Recap: Fundamentals Block :rewind: {.center}
**What we covered in Lectures 1--4**: - **Scarcity** forces choices :arrow_right: trade-offs everywhere - **Economic Systems**: Market, Centralized, Mixed - **Opportunity Cost** = accounting cost + surplus of the best alternative - **PPF**: Visualizes society's production trade-offs and efficiency **Today**: We zoom in from society to the **individual consumer** :point_right: How does a single person decide what to buy?
## Welcome to Consumer Theory :shopping_cart: {.center}
**The Big Question**: Given limited income and market prices, what can a consumer afford? :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} **Lectures 5--9 Roadmap**: 5. :point_right: **Budget Set & Constraint** (today) 6. Preferences & Rationality Axioms 7. MRS, Utility & Maximization 8. Individual & Market Demand 9. Demand Elasticity ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} **Why it matters for tourism** :airplane: Tourists are consumers! Understanding budget constraints explains: - Why some choose hostels, others choose resorts - How exchange rates affect travel decisions - Why "all-inclusive" packages exist ::: ::::
# The Consumer's Problem ## Starting Point: What Can You Afford? :money_with_wings:
Every consumer faces **three constraints**: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="33%"} :moneybag: **Income** ($M$) The total money available to spend ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} :label: **Price of Good 1** ($p_1$) How much each unit of good 1 costs ::: ::: {.column width="34%"} :label: **Price of Good 2** ($p_2$) How much each unit of good 2 costs ::: :::: ::: {.key-concept} **The Consumer's Problem** Given income $M$ and prices $p_1$, $p_2$, what combinations of goods 1 and 2 can the consumer purchase? :::
## A Tourism Example :palm_tree:
**Scenario**: A tourist arrives in Lisbon with a daily budget of **€100**. :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} **Two "goods" to spend on**: - :fork_and_knife: **Meals** at restaurants: €20 each - :ticket: **Museum tickets**: €10 each **Question**: What combinations of meals and museum visits can this tourist afford? ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} | Meals ($x_1$) | Museums ($x_2$) | Total Spent | |:-:|:-:|:-:| | 0 | 10 | €100 | | 1 | 8 | €100 | | 2 | 6 | €100 | | 3 | 4 | €100 | | 5 | 0 | €100 | ::: ::::
## The Budget Constraint Equation :straight_ruler:
The consumer spends **all** income on two goods: $$\underbrace{p_1 \cdot x_1 + p_2 \cdot x_2}_{Expenditure} = \underbrace{M}_{Budget}$$ **From our example**: €20 $\cdot x_1$ + €10 $\cdot x_2$ = €100 Solving for $x_2$ (to graph it): $$x_2 = \frac{M}{p_2} - \frac{p_1}{p_2} \cdot x_1$$ $$x_2 = \frac{100}{10} - \frac{20}{10} \cdot x_1 = 10 - 2x_1$$
## Graphing the Budget Constraint :chart_with_downwards_trend: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture05-budget_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){fig-align='center' width=1056} ::: ::: ## Key Elements of the Budget Constraint
:::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} **Intercepts** (maximum of each good): - **Vertical** ($x_1 = 0$): $\frac{M}{p_2} = \frac{100}{10} = 10$ museums - **Horizontal** ($x_2 = 0$): $\frac{M}{p_1} = \frac{100}{20} = 5$ meals ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} **Slope** of the budget line: $$\text{Slope} = -\frac{p_1}{p_2} = -\frac{20}{10} = -2$$ :point_right: For every **1 extra meal**, the tourist gives up **2 museum visits** This is the **economic rate of substitution** set by the market! Also known as the **opportunity cost** of an extra meal! ::: ::::
## Budget Set vs Budget Line :world_map:
::: {.key-concept} **Budget Line** vs **Budget Set** - **Budget Line** All bundles where the consumer spends *exactly* all income: $p_1 x_1 + p_2 x_2 = M$ - **Budget Set** All *affordable* bundles (spend all or less): $p_1 x_1 + p_2 x_2 \leq M$ The budget set is the **shaded area** including the line itself. ::: Bundles **above** the budget line are **unaffordable** :x: Bundles **on** the budget line: spend all income :white_check_mark: Bundles **inside** the budget set: affordable with money left over :white_check_mark:
# What Shifts the Budget Constraint? ## Change in Income :chart_with_upwards_trend:
**What happens if our tourist's budget increases from €100 to €150?**
::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture05-budget_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){fig-align='center' width=1056} ::: :::
:point_right: Income change: **parallel shift** (slope unchanged at $-p_1/p_2$)
## Change in Price of Good 1 :label:
**What if meal prices drop from €20 to €10?**
::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture05-budget_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){fig-align='center' width=1056} ::: :::
:point_right: Price change of **one** good: **pivot** around the other intercept (slope changes!)
## Summary: What Shifts What? :memo:
| Change | Effect on Budget Line | Slope | Intercepts | |:--|:--|:-:|:-:| | :arrow_up: Income ($M$) | Parallel shift **outward** | Same | Both increase | | :arrow_down: Income ($M$) | Parallel shift **inward** | Same | Both decrease | | :arrow_down: Price $p_1$ | Pivot **outward** on $x_1$ axis | Flatter | $x_1$-intercept increases | | :arrow_up: Price $p_1$ | Pivot **inward** on $x_1$ axis | Steeper | $x_1$-intercept decreases | | :arrow_down: Price $p_2$ | Pivot **outward** on $x_2$ axis | Steeper | $x_2$-intercept increases | | :arrow_up: Price $p_2$ | Pivot **inward** on $x_2$ axis | Flatter | $x_2$-intercept decreases |
:bulb: **Key insight**: The slope $-p_1/p_2$ is the **relative price** — what the *market* says one good costs in terms of the other. ## The Slope as Opportunity Cost :balance_scale:
The slope of the budget constraint has a direct economic interpretation: $$\text{Slope} = -\frac{p_1}{p_2}$$ This tells us the **market's exchange rate** between the two goods. :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} **Our example**: $-20/10 = -2$ For 1 extra meal, you **must** give up 2 museum visits. This is **not** a preference — it is a constraint imposed by prices! ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} :point_right: Compare with the **PPF slope** from Lecture 4 - PPF slope: society's opportunity cost (technology) - Budget line slope: individual's opportunity cost (prices) **Both represent trade-offs, at different scales!** ::: ::::
# Tourism Applications ## Application: Exchange Rates & Tourist Budgets :euro:
**How exchange rates shift a tourist's budget constraint** A British tourist visits Portugal with **£500** to spend on: - :hotel: **Accommodation**: €80/night - :fork_and_knife: **Dining**: €20/meal
:::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} **Scenario A**: £1 = €1.15 Budget in €: £500 × 1.15 = **€575** - Max nights: 575/80 ≈ **7.2** - Max meals: 575/20 ≈ **28.8** ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} **Scenario B**: £1 = €1.30 Budget in €: £500 × 1.30 = **€650** - Max nights: 650/80 ≈ **8.1** - Max meals: 650/20 ≈ **32.5** ::: :::: :point_right: A stronger pound = **parallel outward shift** of the budget constraint in euro terms. The tourist can afford more of *everything*! ## Application: All-Inclusive vs. À La Carte :hotel:
**Why do all-inclusive packages exist?** :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} **À la carte** (standard budget constraint): - Tourist allocates budget freely between accommodation and experiences - Faces standard linear budget line - Trade-offs are clear: more luxury room = fewer excursions ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} **All-inclusive package**: - Fixed price for a **bundle** (room + meals + activities) - Effectively removes the trade-off within the bundle - Budget constraint becomes a **single point** for included goods - Remaining budget: free for souvenirs, extra trips, etc. ::: :::: :bulb: All-inclusive packages simplify the consumer's problem by **pre-selecting** a bundle. We'll revisit this when we study **preferences** in Lecture 6!
## Numerical Example: Step by Step :abacus:
**Problem**: A tourist has **€200** to spend. Surfing lessons cost **€40** each. Fado show tickets cost **€25** each. **Step 1**: Write the budget constraint $$40 x_1 + 25 x_2 = 200$$ **Step 2**: Find intercepts - If $x_1 = 0$: $x_2 = 200/25 = 8$ fado shows - If $x_2 = 0$: $x_1 = 200/40 = 5$ surf lessons **Step 3**: Find the slope $$\text{Slope} = -\frac{p_1}{p_2} = -\frac{40}{25} = -1.6$$ :point_right: 1 extra surf lesson costs 1.6 fado shows **Step 4**: Check an interior bundle — (2 surf, 4 fado): $40(2) + 25(4) = 80 + 100 = 180 \leq 200$ :white_check_mark: (inside budget set, €20 unspent)
## General Formulas: Cheat Sheet :clipboard:
::: {.key-concept} **Budget Constraint Formulas** **Equation**: $p_1 x_1 + p_2 x_2 = M$ **Solved for** $x_2$: $\displaystyle x_2 = \frac{M}{p_2} - \frac{p_1}{p_2} x_1$ **Vertical intercept** ($x_1 = 0$): $\displaystyle \frac{M}{p_2}$ **Horizontal intercept** ($x_2 = 0$): $\displaystyle \frac{M}{p_1}$ **Slope**: $\displaystyle -\frac{p_1}{p_2}$ (the relative price of good 1 in terms of good 2) :::
## Summary: Today's Key Takeaways
**Today's Lecture Integration**: 1. **Income** ($M$) and **prices** ($p_1, p_2$) define the consumer's constraint 2. **Budget line**: $p_1 x_1 + p_2 x_2 = M$ — all bundles spending exactly all income 3. **Budget set**: $p_1 x_1 + p_2 x_2 \leq M$ — all affordable bundles 4. **Slope** = $-p_1/p_2$ = market rate of exchange between goods 5. Income changes :arrow_right: **parallel shift** 6. Price changes :arrow_right: **pivot** (rotation) **Connection to previous lectures**: The budget line is the *individual-level analog* of the PPF — both show feasible combinations and trade-offs. **Next**: Lecture 6 — Consumer **Preferences** and axioms of rationality. We'll ask: *among all affordable bundles, which one does the consumer actually want?*
## Exercises {.center} **Application Time!** :pencil2: Budget constraint calculations and graphical analysis. ## Exercise 1: Multiple Choice
**Question**: A consumer has income $M = 120$, with $p_1 = 15$ and $p_2 = 10$. The slope of the budget constraint is: A. $-10/15$ B. $-15/10$ C. $-120/15$ D. $-120/10$ ::: {.fragment} ::: {.highlight-box} **Answer: B** ::: The slope of the budget line is always $-p_1/p_2 = -15/10 = -1.5$. This means for each additional unit of good 1, the consumer must give up 1.5 units of good 2. Note: income affects the *position* of the line, not its slope. :::
## Exercise 2: Multiple Choice
**Question**: If the price of good 2 **doubles** while income and $p_1$ stay the same, the budget line: A. Shifts outward in parallel B. Pivots inward around the $x_1$-intercept C. Pivots outward around the $x_2$-intercept D. Pivots inward around the $x_2$-intercept ::: {.fragment} ::: {.highlight-box} **Answer: B** ::: When $p_2$ doubles: the $x_2$-intercept ($M/p_2$) **halves** (moves down), while the $x_1$-intercept ($M/p_1$) **stays the same**. So the line **pivots inward around the $x_1$-intercept**. The consumer can buy less of good 2 but the same maximum of good 1. The slope $-p_1/p_2$ becomes smaller in absolute value (the line becomes flatter). :::
## Exercise 3: Open Question
**Scenario**: A Portuguese tourism student plans a weekend trip. She has a budget of **€150**. She wants to split spending between: - :surfing_woman: **Surf lessons**: €30 each ($x_1$) - :wine_glass: **Wine tasting tours**: €25 each ($x_2$) **Questions**: a) Write the budget constraint equation and solve for $x_2$. b) Calculate and interpret the slope. What is the opportunity cost of one surf lesson in terms of wine tastings? c) Find both intercepts. Draw the budget constraint with $x_1$ on the horizontal axis. d) Is the bundle (2 surf lessons, 3 wine tastings) affordable? Is it on the budget line? e) Suppose the student receives a €50 gift card (total budget now €200). Draw the new budget line on the same graph. What changed and what stayed the same? f) Now instead of the gift card, suppose surf lesson prices drop to €25 (budget stays at €150). Draw this new line. How does it differ from part (e)?
## Exercise 3: Solution — Parts a, b, c
**a)** Budget constraint: $30x_1 + 25x_2 = 150$ Solving for $x_2$: $x_2 = \frac{150}{25} - \frac{30}{25}x_1 = 6 - 1.2x_1$ **b)** Slope $= -p_1/p_2 = -30/25 = -1.2$ :point_right: Each surf lesson costs 1.2 wine tastings. The opportunity cost of 1 surf lesson is 1.2 wine tours foregone. **c)** Intercepts: - $x_1 = 0 \Rightarrow x_2 = 150/25 = 6$ wine tastings (vertical intercept) - $x_2 = 0 \Rightarrow x_1 = 150/30 = 5$ surf lessons (horizontal intercept) Graph: straight line from $(0, 6)$ to $(5, 0)$.
## Exercise 3: Solution — Parts d, e, f
**d)** Bundle (2, 3): $30(2) + 25(3) = 60 + 75 = 135 \leq 150$ :white_check_mark: **Affordable?** Yes! **On the budget line?** No — she spends only €135, leaving €15 unspent. The bundle is **inside** the budget set. **e)** New budget €200: $30x_1 + 25x_2 = 200 \Rightarrow x_2 = 8 - 1.2x_1$ - New intercepts: $(0, 8)$ and $(6.67, 0)$ - **Parallel shift outward** — slope unchanged at $-1.2$ **f)** Price drop $p_1 = 25$, $M = 150$: $25x_1 + 25x_2 = 150 \Rightarrow x_2 = 6 - x_1$ - New intercepts: $(0, 6)$ and $(6, 0)$ - **Pivot outward** around vertical intercept — slope changes to $-1$ **Key difference**: (e) is a parallel shift (more of both goods equally); (f) is a pivot (relatively more surf lessons become affordable, wine tasting maximum unchanged).
## Next Lecture {.center} **February 20, 2026**: Consumer Preferences & Axioms of Rationality We answered: *What can the consumer afford?* Next, we ask: *What does the consumer **want**?* :thinking: ## Thank You! {.center} **Questions?** :raising_hand: :email: paulo.fagandini@ext.universidadeeuropeia.pt --- *Next class: Tomorrow, Friday, February 20, 2026*

  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
